												The Good: It will satisfy your RPG thirst... for a while (about 20-30 hours until you hit a grind wall or a realization of a huge game flaw which will be explained later in this review).  The story is decent.  It isn't your cliche cookie cutter story out of a rpg recycling bin, and is good enough to come back for more. There are lots of quests to do, besides the main story line.  In fact, later on, most of the leveling will occur from doing sidequests rather than the main questline.  At any time of the day, there will be a global event for you to participate in and earn gold or gear.  There is a guild system and a PVP system.  There are 2 types of PVP, which I find pretty ingenious.  The first is your regular PVP combat... the more powerful character wins.  The second is where the game equalizes the playing field for both characters.  In other words, a lvl 50 character vs a lvl 10 haracter will have the same exact stats.  This helps newbies become acclimated to the combat system.  THe PVP system is also implemented in a variety of ways.  There are 2v2, 3v3, 1v1 equalized PVP duels.  There are guild wars.  There is a regular 1v1 pvp based on the strength of your character with the AI controlling the opponet.The Bad:It's... yes, you guessed it, a godamn pay to win. I have added a few of the top players (ranked in PVP and level) how they attained their current statuses.  One told me she paid $1000 (no I counted the zeroes correcly) and the top 2 paid over $2k. The items that are purchasable only with electrum (the in game currency only obtainable through cash) are ultra end game gear that have no level requirement.  It takes about a little over $100 USD to gather most of it.  (If you want all of the gear, itll be an upwards of 200, excluding armor upgrades which can become very costly.)  What's worse is that this gear is unobtainable anywhere else.  You MUST pay.  While other games may offer xp boosts, temporary gold gain boosts, or a sweet aesthetic item (like leagues of legends), this game falls within the very definition of pay to win: exclusive ultra gear for those who drop money. (Even Leagues lets you eventually buy champions if you grind hard enough. This game doesn't.)Sadly, it rewards this type of behavior.  Those who pay money, even get to claim more rewards for charging their credit cards.  Consequently, this Pay to Win encouragement totally destroys the guild PVP system out of the water due to the higher tier companies having members who have paid their way to glory.  Aside from the major pay to win flaw, there are other faults with the game.  Item customization is very lackluster.  While there are color rankings for rarity, there is no INHERENT customization of stats.  E.G. Diablo 2 had great item customization in terms of different rare items providing alternate stats to skills and even helped characters gain abilities.  For CoS, the rarer the weapon, the stronger the stat.  Each item adds one stat. (Yes, just one stat... different pieces of gear add different stats)  Item customization is minimal. SO is the skill system. Over the course of your gameplay your character will receive 5 more skills on top of 3 default ones.  You unlock a skill every 5 or 10 levels.  When you do unlock a new skill: you are given a choice of 3 different skills that do different higs.  You pick one and level it up as you progress.  This means, the game has 15 different skills for each character.... as I said, builds are not very diverse.  This is not like D2 where there are vastly different builds... a different build varies by 2 skills. THATS IT.Gameplay is unresponsive and at times, is severely handicappd by lag.  Lag is a reocurring problem as there are only 2 servers.. both located in the US.  As you begin playing, the pay to win problems will be masked by the fact that there are just so many evets abvailable for you to do.  However, as you begin to gain a decent grasp of what the game offers, you slowly realize the huge, lingering grind wall in front of you.  The novelty wears off, and the tedium of grinding begins.  Main quests are the same: dungeon clearing with a boss at the end.   This is when you start searching for alternate methods of lveling faster, as it begins increasingly difficult to reach the next level.  This is where you fall trapped to the pay to win scheme. You begin to think bout spending real cash on offers such as"brand new ultra gear!" "Tired of being ♥♥♥♥♥? SPend 200 dolars and become awesome!"Bottom Line: The game is pure pay to win.  Unbearably and horribly pay to win. Stay away.  It encourages the behaviour with rewards for those who spend money.  Not worth your time. Spend your time elsewhere looking for another RPG.  Not here.

												I started playing City of Steam: Arkadia mostly due to the fact that it was a Steampunk based MMORPG with the fantasy touch that I enjoy added in. The story at the start was interesting and easy to follow, and it held my interest long enough for me to get to level 20 something as one character - which depending on the MMO you play can range from super easy to down right difficult.Now, let's get down to the nitty gritty.../PROS/* Steampunk, Steampunk everywhere. Glorious top hats, goggles, corsets, and a Steambike! * The Story - It has a story, I'll give it that, and one that's actually interesting enough to keep me curious about the next chapter.* Easy-to-get Costume Items - While they do give some perks, via set bonuses or on their own - they are easy to get with daily log on and your 5 free lesser items and your 1 free better item, and if you keep opening those, you eventually can open more boxes to get a chance at the rare set.* Different Battle Options for Classes. I like this, but at the same time it doesn't really do much when half of your ability to kill things depends on your gear that you're actively using.* Mercenaries. A good idea, pretty nice at low level./CONS/* Graphics - They're not all that great, but considering it's a Free MMO, there's not too much you can do [aside from maybe polishing it up, I guess?]* Music/sounds - Music makes a lot of the game for me, and if I have to turn off all sounds just so the game is remotely bareable, then that's a huge issue.* Auto-Battle - While this could be a good thing, it's not. You can set yourself to AFK level and get through things [if you're high enough of a level and item-set] and never talk to anyone in the game ever. If that's your thing, go ahead.* The amount of difficulty ramps up /quickly/. I'm all for a hard game, but when you have an auto-battle system in place, you're pretty much saying "Press button to win" and if you're not paying complete attention to how your gear is set up and when you're using potions, you will die pretty fast, even with things being done for you. The dungeons and other areas aren't marked off by level restrictions like most other games, but by item restrictions. If you don't meet them, even by a mere 20 points, you will be killed off. * Limited Character Customization. This one is self explanitory, but even WoW has more customization in comparison to this game.* Pay-to-Win - Like I stated about difficulty, it ramps up hard if your gear doesn't meet the requirements. Funny thing - If I remember right, Costumes add to that. You can buy really good costume armor and weapons and just glide your way through a good chunk of the game. This also includes Bike skins, pets that also give you stats, as well as mercenaries that can wreck things.* Mercenaries - These guys can make or break you too, as /they/ are also figured into your relative ability to kill things fast so you don't die, even as a tank class.In short - Play at your own risk, this game has more Cons than Pros.

The races are balanced, the concept of the game is very promising...but if you're intending on playing it past the intro, I can't suggest it. All it's good for in the end is going into a dungeon and killing hordes of bugs and mechanical annoyances, which aren't that hard to beat. Even the bosses are easy to take down. As a player of MMOs, I was hoping for more actual fighting and...well, being able to explore the world.As much as I wish I could, I can't recommend this game. Does the story show promise? Yes. Could the game have been more than it is? Yes. The sad part is the developers didn't take that route, and City of Steam: Arkadia seems like it's vastly unfinished in terms of story and exploration.

												The weirdest game I was not playing. Even though I was playing it.Like spectating a really bored gamer playing a boring game.To understand what I mean, you need to know that the game features two vital functions:Auto-run to get to quest locations, and auto-combat which will spam all your skills it can and glug any potions you need for either Health or Mana. (called 'Steam' in this game)And that's all you need to know. If you're not fighting or moving, click the quest marker and your character will go there. Upon which they'll then end up fighting if that is required, which is automatised as well. And in general, the game's enemies are simple enough that, all you would have to do anyway is spam your skills. That's all there is to it.The 'selling point' for this game is that it's a mere 50mb. A nice premise, but there are flashgames out there that take less than 1mb and are tremendously more fun than this. Again, there is no reason to not play this game on auto-mode because in 95% of the time, it is the most efficient way. Not to mention that potions are stupidly cheap to buy in mass ammount, and auto-combat includes auto-looting.In fact, whenever you pick up gear that is a straight upgrade to what's equipped, it will prompt you to equip it. Have skillpoints or stat points to spend? The game will remind you of this and offer a convenient 'automatic' button that'll spend these in the amount best suited to your class.Everything in this game is designed to remove any thought process from you. You choose a class, choose a race with a handful of variations, have a VERY basic array of options to change your hair (the face is stuck with the one of the 'race presets' you picked) aaaaand... that's it. Press quest marker to continue.There are games out there that make tremendous usage with little space. They draw you in, even if their style happens to be 8-bit. And then there's games that use very little space, and have absolutely nothing to show for that feat. City of Steam just doesn't bring anything worthwhile to the table.Don't get me wrong, it doesn't do anything particularly horribly bad. If anything, what the game does is simply somewhat sub-par, beneath the commonly accepted standard across the board. This game just enables you to turn it into a lazy man's game, a detriment to an already unimpressive title.Honestly, this shouldn't be on PC. This should just be on iOS and Android and it would flourish like crazy. games that size are not uncommon and it wouldn't be impossible to translate the controls.Maybe it already is on mobile devices, but I'm having a mighty hard time finding it.I would really just say... don't bother with it unless you've got absolutely nothing else to do and you want to spend that free time on something that won't enrage you.But neither will it really engage you.

												First, the bad news. The first time you do a (level 10?) dungeon (PER character), expect the game to lock the dungeon reward screen on you to the point you have exit out of the game. Near as I can tell, this only happence once per character. For good or bad, you get 5 characters per account. Any server you log into will show any characters you have already made.The game is sometimes hard to log into. They seem to be working hard on content and bugs. I got fairly quick responses to the emails I sent to them, and have edited and kept this review updated accordingly.Next, the good news. Its actually worth dealing with bugs till they fix it.  My husband and I discovered this game on the same day, and as we played, it seemed every 10 minutes or so we were finding something new that we loved about the game. I haven't seen him this hooked in a loong time.  I've paid it the highest compliment I know how for a game... I created a solo... I almost never solo.  Yeah, its that much fun. If you like steampunk at all, you want to give it a shot. Yes, the character creation is exceedingly limited, and the classes *seem* limited. Trust me, by level 6 or so you dont care. The classes have variations within them. And the looks of the character constantly develop in game, given a combination of luck and your taste.They are generous with rewards for those who log in every day for up to seven days in a row, and have a constantly changing event giving out new rewards simply for being logged in and playing on any given day. Almost everything you do has a completion reward, collection reward, something extra built into it. It may sound overwhelming, but give yourself a day and you will find that they did an excellent job of helping you track it. While it may seem too easy at first, you really come to  appreciate their ingenious ways of helping you to track as you level up and find more to keep track of.Now something that some will see as horrible and others as excellent... I happen to love it. This game reaches new heights in pitting brain vs brawn. If all you do is push to level up to max in one weekend, you could find yourself with a level 50 character with little better than level 10 abilities. Every time I play I find new ways they give to make your character unique. There are miriad ways to buy, build, plan, level everything about your character, and every level counts. Each time you finish your quest and level up, take the time to look around, did you do your dailies and level up your abilities? Do you spend more on your merc(battle pet, in essense) or more on your armor, or more on your abilities? Do you buy more bag space or a better buff pet? All choices are good, and all take time to build.  If you love to do a slow, thorough build of your character, like I do, you will find this game addictive. If you are all about the max level as fast as possible, you may find yourself a little frustrated with having to slow down and plan your character. Either player type given time can find themselves addicted to this game. Hope this review helps. Keep up the good work!

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												City of Steam: Arkadia starts out fairly charming with pleasant music, respectable visuals, and nice atmosphere.Leveling starts out extremely rapid, almost too quickly. Each quest rewards a full level up until level 16 or so.Quest related dungeons are not solo/party instanced, you will find yourself competing with other players and potentially losing out on rewards due to other players rushing the boss.There is also the "Casual" mode, where you can tell your character to auto attack and it proceeds to wreak havoc until 1. the objective is complete, 2. you tell it to stop, 3. it dies. I actually found this feature rather amusing.The cash shop itself is reasonable for a f2p, you can buy boosts, materials, pets that collect loot, mounts in the form of jetpacks, and cosmetics. Nothing too outragous.There are quite a few bugs, some not so bad while others will render the game unplayable until you email support and get them to fix it. The support crew are very quick and my account was repaired in less than one business day. (Mercenary Tutorial quest at level 11 completely disabled my curser ingame and removed parts of the UI)Recharging cash shop currency gets you premium weapon skins with large stat buffs (I was willing to overlook this)Spending cash shop currency also unlocks rewards.All of the above didn't seem like much of an issue, but one thing that really got my attention were the Subscription perks.Subscribers also get collectible stamps every day that can be redeemed in the Collections menu for permenant stat boosts.I don't want to call this game pay to win, so I'll let this screenshot say it:


City of Steam: Arkadia 
A Screenshot of City of Steam: Arkadia
By: Aedensin




If you can overlook all of the above, you can have a decently fun time. There are events held almost hourly including huge boss raids, wilderness boss hunts, PvP tournaments, events that give free ingame currency, and events to collect free experience.Not to mention Modding, where you insert mods into armor and weapons to alter their stats and their appearance (appearance alteration is only for weapons+shields). This is my favorite feature, unfortantely mods seem to be somewhat hard to come by. I've only found 2 or 3 on my own. Also mods come in different shapes and you must match the shapes with compatible slots in your gear, which is very frustrating.I still find certain charm in City of Steam: Arkadia, but I would not recomend this game to my friends.

Posted: March 8, 2014
												In all honesty this game isn't as bad as many of the negative reviews make it out to be. Many of them are plain wrong, after logging into the game for 5 minutes and selecting the admittedly stupid "relaxed" playstyle they complain that there is no fullscreen and the game plays its self, while the combat is incredibly dull and generic its not quite as bad as so many have made it out to be, and the fullscreen option is presented to you right at the main menu.While not the worst game I've ever played, and not as bad as several negative reviews claim, I cannot honestly reccommend it to anyone but the most bored of individuals seeking something that not only wants your money, but your time afterwards. So far as I can tell from the relatively short time I played this game, the subscription model is rather odd, you pay for a basic subscription (if you so choose to of course) and over time as you play, your exploits within the game upgrade said subscription to higher tiers in order to recieve more bonuses. As someone who enjoys MMORPGs thoroughly I understand that they are a medium for making money, no matter how much love is put into the game, so I can't complain about that fact in its self, but it seems rather odd that after you make a purchase the game requires you to play it to get more out of it. Now before you say "But you're going to play the game anyway, why is it a problem?" the issue I have with it is that when you do pay you still aren't guaranteed your moneys worth of in game advantages, Now I don't normally pay in free games anyway, but if I'm going to pay a subscription, then Im definitely not going to play the game exactly the same slow grinding way that someone who isnt would be.That brings me to another point, grind. Now I will admit I played this game for a relatively short time considering how much content any MMO brings to the table, theres plenty that I didn't do, however there was  one thing that I did do, and that was grind. Grind grind grind. Now grinding isnt always a bad thing, some people enjoy it, in fact, I do myself to an extent, but every quest felt EXACTLY the same. The description and lead up might seem like you're going to go collect something or find something but either way, 99% of the quest objective required to complete the quest its self, was summed up by 2 little bars under what most of the time was your "Dungeon objective," an experience bar, and a shillings bar. In order for you to complete nearly any real objective (excluding standard 'go talk to this fellow' quests) you are directed to an open instance in which you pretty much just murder everything for a minute or two, click a shiny clearly visible objective, and leave. Sometimes you have to kill a boss as well, but with the volume of people inside the instance with you, you normally don't have to actually kill it, in fact you dont even have to hit the thing, you can walk in and someone can get the killing blow on the boss creature and you instantly get credit for the kill as well. The combat its self doesnt aid in making the grinding any more enjoyable. I myself played a warder, the warrior class of City of Steam. While the class had some interesting mechanics, one of which being switching between equipped weapon sets to boost different stats, the combat is generally uninteresting and bland. You have a resource, you have health, you have some buttons. You click, character whacks, you press a button should you feel the need to (I rarely did) and then numbers and death proceed to spread everywhere.The game's aesthetic design however is somewhat nice, I 'll give it that, but only to a certain degree. The game has some decent style despite having relatively dated graphics, however this style is quickly ruined by the vast amount of clutter and dull color palette used within the game. Being steampunk focused, I can't expect too many color splashes, but the way that the game is presented with its browns and metallic grays just makes the game look confusing and crowded. On the note of aesthetics I will say the character customization is okay, all of the races look relatively interesting... all but one... the only one I wanted to play. That being the orcs. Now every race in this game has SOMETHING about them that makes them look a little stupid, whether it be a somewhat silly facial expression locked on their face, a strange array of hairstyles, huge ears etc, but the orcs just downright look terrible, and I love orcs, so this made me sad. Their hair looked glued onto their heads, their moustaches looked like paper cutouts hanging under their noses, and the beards looked no better. Well at least I looked pretty neat on the free motorcycle dressed in my overly badass level 5 armor.Yes I said motorcycle. Everyone gets one for free very early in game, as far as I know this is the only mount in the game. The motorcylce can be upgraded with vehicle parts to go faster and look cooler (though I thought the last several upgrades available looked less like badass steampunk motorcycles and more like something I would unlock in Mario Kart) but the upgrades are another way of getting your money, you need more and more parts to upgrade it, and one of the ways you can get them is connected to the payment system.All in all the game is by no means the worst game I've ever played, and I admit I didnt play very much, but the first impression is always the strongest in an MMO, and sometimes you can just tell when an MMO will play the same throughout, this was a strong feeling with this game in particular.I wouldnt recommend it to anyone, however I do encourage you to try it if you really wish to, theres no large download to deal with, in fact I assume that only those with the slowest of internet connections can download the game within 30 seconds, the game downloaded in less than ten for myself. In fact by the time I had clicked on my steam library to confirm it was downloading it was already finished. You don't have much to lose aside from an hour or two of time becoming disappointed.

												This game is pretty good. It isn't supposed to be this good. I mean it's web based (although that doesn't really mean anything nowdays, since html 5, and unity web player), runs on a potato, and needs like 60 MB hard disk space. But it's suprisingly fun! The graphics look pretty good! The models are detailed, textures aren't that blurry, I can say it looks the same as WoW. It's just much more fun! You can play in TPS style, or in "2.5d" (kind of like Neverwinter Nights or Baldur's Gate). Plays much more like an actual crpg, than any other mmo-s i have tried. The character development system gives you much more freedom over your character. Your choice if you want to have more accuracy, more health or more armor. The actual gameplay is like in similar mmo-s, you have your skills, that you can upgrade, some of them are aoe, some of them are cc, you have seen it before. There are pets, you have a steambike you can upgrade (and even change the looks of your "mount", like to a mech). There aren't many customization options at character creation, but after that, you can have like a hundred different steampunk clothing pieces, and accessories. Also there is a pretty interesting mercenary system. Crafting is there, but that only upgrades your gear in a variety of ways. There are events constantly, like boss killing, clearing dungeons for rewards, asynch pvp besides normal 1v1 arena, and of course the hillarious golden egg smasher event.Oh yeah, rewards. You get a sh*tload of rewards just for playing the game, xp, money, crafting materials, you name it. You get rewards for being online, you get rewards for being offline, you get rewards for everything!So is it pay to win? Well if there are still games that are pay to win, this game is the complete opposite. You get shop currency as rewards (bound electrum), only a few items can be bought with paid currency (unbound electrum), and you can get that, if you manage to sell something on the market, without spending a dime. You even find subscriptions as item drops.I have only one problem with the game. The dungeons (especially the early ones) look boring, and they aren't that long either, however you can always go deeper, where stronger monsters wait for you. The developers did a pretty good work on this game. If you are looking for an mmo, with original ideas, and not something along the line of WoW, just give it a try.I absolutely recommend this!

I have followed it's development from the get go, and have watched it's evolution and how this small team has overcome some legitimately substantial obstacles in the name of getting their game out in the world and breathing on it's own.  I love the steampunk vibe this game has, and they have crafted a world and backstory that could well be the fodder for a good novel.  The races are all distinct with cultures and quirks (Though at last play, i noticed the simplified character race descriptions were gone from the character creation screen.  Likely a bug.. (There ARE a good few of those, though they are always working on it.  Indie - you know how it goes) The gameplay is pretty standard MMO fare, but its also very easy to pick up and run with.  The city itself can be rather overwhelming when you first enter.  It is much more than a traditional games faction hub - WoW's Orgrimar or Dalaran look like roadside tomato stands next to the shear scope of the city here - and with good reason - That city is where all the action is.  You adventure into old ruined quarters, forgotten sewers, and things of that nature instead of ventring off over the hills...  There is a lot to see, and the different districts all have pretty neat style and flavor.  If you like steampunk stuff, you will likely spend good time just admireing the design quirks and details in the different districts.  Combat is fast paced, and generally fun though I do have a gripe concerning the fast monster respawn rate - perhaps owing to this games roots as a browser based program, and the limited instancing, monsters continuously respawn - you clear out an abandoned courtyard, turn around to kill a thing in the alleyway, and turn back to find 4 more monsters in the courtyard.   Makes it feel like a meatgrinder, and eliminates the "Room Clear - move on!!" element of a dungeon crawl in a typical game.. (In fairnes I havent played for a while - this may have been fixed.  I need to dive in and see, but this is the way it was, at least.)  Gear is neat and varied, they have a crafting system, spells are cool enough  and the whole thing is lightweight enough to run on pretty much anything.  (Big point.)  The only other real  talking point i want to bring up is the whole "Arcadia" element.  Originally this game was simply "City of Steam" Published by another company that had a small stable of MMO type games.  That company started to do badly, and the folks at Mechanist really wanted to save their baby, so they bought the rights back, and self published - no small achievement, and also part of how it came to Steam.  Now, presumably due to copyright issues or licensing things they needed another name.  That led to City of Steam: Arcadia" being born.  Along with the new name, they added this Arcadia realm where you can participate in games and fish and do other powerup related stuff.   Problem is, for me at least, it seemed tacked on, and sort of pointless.   I thought the game had better feel without it, but all told its not that big of a deal.. Bottom line, this game has a lot of charm and character - it is original, while still incorporating a lot of the stalwart features you would expect from a big money developer.  It's a little rough in places, but this isnt Blizzard.  This is a few guys from (Canada/UK - dont remember) who moved to China to found a small studio to build the game they wanted to build.  This is an indie studio and the game is their labor of love.  For the size of the team, what they have created is astounding.  I would very much recommend you give it a shot!

Posted: April 19, 2014
												Gameplay in City of Steam is very reminiscent of most action RPGs on the market today. In fact, quite a favorable comparison could be made to Diablo 2 or Torchlight 2 from the standpoint that players work to level up skills to make them more powerful. On first glance, City of Steam's combat system is terrific and it certainly isn't bad by any stretch of the imagination. What is boils down to is that it is uninspiring in ways that the aforementioned games are not. As players level, they are granted skill power-ups in one of three disciplines. Points are allotted according to a player's wishes and combat skills are granted. In the end, it's not that the combat system is poor, it's just so much more button mashing of 1-2-3, rinse repeat. Players are faced with pretty standard fare and work from a belt of abilities learned over time that increase in damage and effectiveness. I played as a Warder and my character had the typical arcing swings of both a great sword and two one-handed swords. It's pretty cool that players can choose a second weapon set for different skills and ways to fight monsters. Weapons can be changed out on the fly and it's worth having that ranged weapon handy to aggro only the monsters you want to rush out.Questing is pretty standard fare as well. Head to a quest hub, grab 3-4 quests, head to the instances needed for completion, turn them in and done. Again, it's not unusual, just uninspiring and not as well done as most. The quest givers are not voiced which, depending on your particular style, is either a good or bad thing. Players can utilize an isometric over the shoulder camera or toggle a free ranging camera on the fly. This is a marvelous touch on behalf of Mechanist, something that most players will like very much. In addition, questing can be directed if a player gets lost simply by clicking on the directional arrow that will automatically take characters to the desired location. Still in the end, combat gets repetitive very fast. Between the same look and feel of all the instances and mashing the same combination of buttons over and over, it's a rather tiresome affair.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												Normally a browser-based MMORPG, this game uses the Unity Engine for its 3D Power. For those of you not aware, Unity is a 3D Game/Model engine similar to that of Unreal and other engines in the market. It uses FMOD for Audio. All in all, the game is very "Pay to Win," you can buy a lot of "Power" with real money, in fact, the "Auction House" uses that same real money digital currency, known as Electrum in-game. The game has a few faults, though it's only recently been released. For instance, you cannot move the quest tracker, you cannot move the chat box. Some other normal MMORPG amenities aren't in it, such as auto-decline duels, guild invites, etc. As well as basic chat filters, so you don't have to look at world chat on the first tab of game chat.The audio in the game is pretty clear, but it sometimes cuts for a split-second randomly. This may be due to the audio engine it uses. There is very little customization for characters, but being mostly a browser-based MMORPG, I was expecting no customizability at all. The game even allows you to turn off costumes, showing individual armor models.The game is mostly instance-based, yet the instances usually have all types of players going through them. (This is only experience up to level 10 or so. I am unsure about higher levels.)Like most browser-based MMORPGs, costumes bought through the cash shop usually give stats, as well as mounts giving passive stats such as attack, etc. (As do cash shop pets.) If you don't mind "Pay To Win" then this game is a nice little browser-based or Unity-Based gem.

												Edit:♥♥♥♥♥♥customer service, bugs with item mods, Real money items can be spent and vanish for no reason via Bugs. "Bug" forums that lock your topics without resolution... ♥♥♥♥ this game.Well I've been tooling about with this game for a while and figured I would write a review for it. (Mmo pedigree: Alodds, Runes of Magic, Guild Wars, Rift, WoW, Dying Earth) All things considered my impression of this game has been mostly positive. If you don't choose "Hardcore" mode at the start you can expect a very easy ride for the first 10 levels. The auto combat mode may be a turn off for some but it is optional and disabled during PVP. The graphics are quite attractive (more so if you appreciate Steampunk I imagine). I can only run it with an acceptable framerate on low setting due to a crappy pc but it still looks quite nice.The "pay" aspects DO afford some benifits but nowhere near as breaking as other games I have played (Looking at you Runes of Magic...) My friend bought me a silver pack. The jetpack and pet have proven useful but nowhere near unbalancing past level 10 where their stat bonuses start to become irrelavant.My only sincere complaint is that traditional grinding is IMPOSSIBLE. After a certain amount of kills in an instance you will cease gaining xp. Online and offline training helps to offset this but if you enjoy grinding off your progress it's a sad note.As far as content goes besides the main questline and optional quests you have PVP, Team Arenas, Paragon Dungeons, Monster Lairs, Vanquisher Raids, World Boss raids and a bunch of other goodies (Though there is a daily limit to each catagory of instance which shouldn't be an issue unless you're an addictive personality. Like me. >.<)All in all there are several small ways I could picture this game improving. But for a small investment of cash or for free it is certainly worthy of exploration.

												This is definetely the best MMORPG I've ever played. The controls are simple in the steampunk world, mostly the same as any other in the genre, but this game brings more to the table. With a very simple and unrestricting story line, you are free to play any way you want. Whether you play for the PvP and make your way to the top of the leaderboard, or you play a story based game, or you just mess around with your friends, the game is always exciting to use. I have played for almost 300 hours now (mostly AFK since you get rewards for being AFK) and the whole game has been constantly rewarding. The game has so many rewarding features that no other MMORPG has, and they all make this the greatest MMORPG I've ever seen.There is also NO need to purchase anything with actual money in the game. Everything can be gained with a little elbow grease and time. Of course though, this game should not be so sparing. If you had to pay for a subscription in this game, I would do so gladly, even more gladly than games such as World of Warcraft and ESO. This is a have to have for anyone who wants a new spin on the the repetitive MMORPG genre.
